column4: I have a few questions about 3G radios under linux and what can be done with them....Is there a way to access the phone number assigned to the card by the carrier and use it to place and receive phone calls?
your service provider probably specifically disallows that kind of usage, and may not even allow calls to be routed to the device
Probbaly, but, I still want to try. =) You would be surprised what backdoors there are if you look.
given what i know from my previous employer, a major US telecom and cell phone provider, i'd say there's no chance you could get it working with them, anyway :)
Well, wth the proper mopds on my BB, I have full net access and dont pay for a data plan at all. So, I still want to experiment.
i believe that - but i don't think that a data-only device is provisioned the same way as a voice device with data capability is
I'm going to be using a sim designated for both voice and data to begin with.
oh well in that case, you can probably get that working - i was assuming your sim was only for a data device
i was thinking the restriction would be the provisioning on the carrier end
I'm going to try both, ultimately, but....The first attempt is not data only.
look into the openmoko project - there might be some software for the 3g radio that you can look at that's somewhat relevant
they probably only look at people who are using almost 5gb per month
One of these days I;d like to pick your brain on carrier end filters for data networks.
i don't have a whole lot of specialized knowledge about the phone network - i worked in the it services division
know this: deep packet inspection is real, and it's used in industry
Ah......Hmmmm.....Wonder why I havent been tagged for my net access yet. Been doing it for years.
Could be....I dopnt get close to that...
